block.p: INTERNATIONAL A3-9

New Iraq Plan Shows Signs Of Slowing Death Squads Nearly two months into the new Baghdad security push, there has been some success in reducing the number of death squad victims each day. While over all death rates for all of Iraq have not dropped significantly, a few parts of the capital have become calmer as some death squads have decided to lie low. A1

Moktada al-Sadr, the Shiite cleric and power broker, exhorted Iraqi security forces to unite with his militiamen to show their objections to the American military in Diwaniya, an embattled southern city in Iraq. He did not go so far as to call for violent confrontation. A8

Freed Britons May Sell Stories Some of the 15 British sailors and marines captured and released by Iran seemed to have decided they have a story to sell. In a highly unusual decision, Britain's Ministry of Defense acknowledged that it had agreed to permit them to offer their experiences for sale to newspapers and television stations. A9

Captors Give Israel Demands Hamas militants said that they had sent Israel a list of Palestinian prisoners to be released in exchange for an Israeli soldier they have held for over 10 months. Israeli news media quoted unidentified Israeli officials as saying that they had received the list, but a spokesman for the prime minister's office would not confirm the reports. A9

Captain Cites Currents in Crash The captain of a cruise ship that slammed into a volcanic reef before sinking off the island of Santorini blamed strong sea currents for the crash, Greece's state-run television reported. A4

Iran Searches for Ex-U.S. Agent A Foreign Ministry spokesman, Mohammad Ali Hosseini, said Iran was searching for a former F.B.I. agent, Robert Levinson, who has been missing in Iran for almost a month. He disappeared when he was on the Iranian island of Kish, where he was reported to be working on a film. A9
NATIONAL A10-14

Army Sharply Increases Prosecution of Deserters Army prosecutions of desertion and other unauthorized absences have risen sharply in the last four years, resulting in thousands more negative discharges and prison time for both junior soldiers and combat-tested veterans of the wars in Iraq and Afghanistan.

Hunger Strike at Guantánamo A new hunger strike has broken out at the American detention center at Guantánamo Bay, Cuba, with more than a dozen prisoners subjecting themselves to daily force-feeding to protest their treatment, military officials and lawyers for the detainees said.

Ranchers Fight Land Acquisition In Colorado, a proposed expansion of the Army's Piñon Canyon Maneuver Site threatens to uproot local ranchers, who are set to testify before state lawmakers in support of a bill that would keep the Army from acquiring nearly a half-million acres for training grounds.

Gingrich Criticizes Gonzales Former House Speaker Newt Gingrich became the latest Republican to criticize Attorney General Alberto R. Gonzales for the dismissals of eight United States attorneys and said Mr. Gonzales should consider resigning.
Trial in Minister's Death Jury selection begins today in McNairy County, Tenn., in the unusual case involving a woman who is accused in the killing of her husband, a minister.
OBITUARIES A14-15
Sol LeWitt An artist whose deceptively simple geometric sculptures, drawings and wall paintings established him as a lodestar of modern American art, he was 78. A15
Johnny Hart The creator of the award- winning ''B.C.'' comic strip, he was 76. A14
NEW YORK/REGION B1-5

Construction to Resume On New Subway Line The Second Avenue subway, which has had at least three groundbreakings in the last 40 years, is getting another on Thursday when Gov. Eliot Spitzer gives a speech and hoists a pickax, symbolically beginning construction again where it left off three decades ago. A1

Program for Black Students While many school districts have long worked to close the achievement gap between minority and white students, the Ossining, N.Y., school system has placed its second- and third-grade African-American boys in a special mentoring program in an effort to get black male students to college. A1

Town Succumbs to Sprawl The 400-acre Washington Town Center near Trenton, designed as a remedy to suburban sprawl, has become a victim of its own success: So many families have flocked to Washington Township that the schools are overflowing, property taxes are skyrocketing and the main streets are clogged. B1
SPORTSMONDAY D1-8
Johnson Wins Masters Zach Johnson won his first major championship and second PGA Tour victory at the Masters Tournament, following one of the most difficult weeks in the event's history. D1

Searching for the 'Big Horse' Which 3-year-old thoroughbred will take the nation's breath away in the Kentucky Derby and, for at least two weeks, conjure thoughts of a Triple Crown? The conversation is focusing on two colts: Nobiz Like Shobiz and Street Sense. D6
ARTS E1-8

Maestro Passes Baton Esa-Pekka Salonen, who has led the Los Angeles Philharmonic as music director for 15 seasons, has decided to leave the orchestra when his term ends in 2009, and will be succeeded by Gustavo Dudamel of Venezuela, one of the hottest -- and youngest -- conducting properties around.
E1
BUSINESS DAY C1-10

New Bidders, Old Airwaves Frontline Wireless, an emerging Silicon Valley investment group, is preparing to challenge cellphone, cable and satellite companies for a valuable radio spectrum that will be freed up when television broadcasters convert to digital signals. C1

Keeping the Printers Rolling Despite record revenue and profit, Hewlett-Packard is worried that people are growing accustomed to reading only on-screen. The company is devising ways to get customers to print more Web pages. C1
Business Digest C2
EDITORIAL A16-17
Editorials: Another layer of scandal; circuit breaker; costly contraceptives; Lawrence Downes on Barack Obama and Hawaii.
Columns: Bob Herbert, Paul Krugman.
